question: Question_01_(d)
sols:
We use the substitution

\[u= \cos(x)\] then we have

\[du= -\sin(x) \,dx\] and

\[\displaystyle
\sin^2 (x)=1-u^2\]

Therefore

\[\displaystyle
\sin^3(x) \,dx = (1-u^2) (-1) du = (u^2-1) du\]

Consequently

\[\int \sin^3(x) dx = \int (u^2-1) du = \frac {u^3} 3 - u = \frac{\cos^3(x)} 3 - \cos(x)\]

And so we can compute the integral

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{\pi} \sin^3(x) \,dx &= \frac{\cos^3(x)} 3 - \cos(x) \Bigr|_0^{\pi} \\
&= (-1/3+1) - (1/3-1)\\
&= 4/3
\end{align*} and the correct answer is E.
hints: Then use the substitution that allows you to use the chain rule simply.
